children.value: , a static site generator for React.
: a simple portfolio with pages and projects
: an introduction based on the example project.

plugins: [
    {
      resolve: `gatsby-source-filesystem`,
      options: {
        name: `src`,
        path: `${__dirname}/src/`,
      },
    },
    {
      resolve: 'gatsby-plugin-cockpit',
      options: {
        cockpitConfig: {
          baseURL: 'http://localhost:8888',
          folder: '/cockpit',
          accessToken: '4d659efb084077fd24aeb4871d4386',
          collections: ['posts'],
          regions: ['footer'],
          customComponents: [],
        },
      },
    },
  ],
The url to you Cockpit installation
The folder of your Cockpit installation
A valid API access token to you cockpit installation. See the
The specific Cockpit collections you want to fetch. If empty all collections will be fetched.
The specific Cockpit regions you want to fetch. If empty all regions will be fetched.
If you have defined some custom components for you cockpit layout fields and want them to be parsed for image fields.
Collections are converted into nodes. For example a

allPost {
    edges {
        nodes {
            id
            ...
        }
    }
}
Assets are converted into Gatsby filesystem files and can be fetched with

allFile {
    edges {
        nodes {
            id
            publicURL
            ...
        }
    }
}
Regions are available in GraphQL as region nodes. So if you have a
field you can use following GraphQL query:

footer: region(name: { eq: "footer" }) {
	values {
		col1
		col2
	}
}

hProperties.aria-label: query child nodes from cockpit fields permalink

children.value: Query Child Nodes From Cockpit Fields
fields will be parsed and transform into corresponding GraphQL nodes.
The CollectionLink field links a collection to another collection. Here an example with

allPlayer {
	edges {
        nodes {
            name
            role
            team {
                name
            }            
        }
	}
}
The asset field gets extended with a
attribute linking to the corresponding file node.
For example, if you have a
collection with a name and a pdf as an asset field. So You can get the PDF URL with following GraphQL query:

allCandidate {
	edges {
        nodes {
            name
            pdf {
            	localFile {
	                publicURL                    
            	}
            }            
        }
	}
}
Like the asset field, the image field gets extended with a
attribute linking to the corresponding file node.
collection with title, content and preview. You can use
in your GraphQL query and take advantage of Gatsby’s image processing features.

allPost {
	edges {
        nodes {
            title
            content
            preview {
            	localFile {
                    childImageSharp {
                        sizes(maxWidth: 2000, quality: 90) {
                            ...GatsbyImageSharpSizes_withWebp
                        }
                    }                    
            	}
            }            
        }
	}
}
The layout field enables us to visually arrange components. It is even possible to define custom components corresponding to React Components we will us in Gatsby. This may be done with the
collection with title and content. You can do the following query:

allPage {
	edges {
        nodes {
            title
            content {
            	component
		        settings {
                    # component fields
                    ...
		        }
            }    
            content_parsed
            content_files {
                id
                publicURL
                # normal file node
            }
        }
	}
}
gives you the components with their settings
gives you the the same than field name but in an object. It enables you to ignore the type of components in the query and just getting all the component settings.
gives you all the file nodes present in the layout.
